commentBody: Wow, I blew through that one in a hurry.  Not that challenging or right in my wheelhouse. Can't decide which.
Oh, I've been to the Bahla Fort. Good news: one day away from my first ever Golden Month. Bad news: tomorrow is Sunday. Easy 12 minute solve
The easiest Saturday I've ever done.

I think you were right, Maddy; this was a fine Friday!

I really wanted to COMETOnothing, 
but I was pleased to COMETOABADEND.

Otherwise, no DRAGONS here,
nor URBANDECAY.

I'll take the MINIDONUTS, and I don't want to hear complaints about the BRANDNAME in the grid.

I MEANIT.

HereBeDragons is a remarkably fun answer; but even more enjoyable was Caitlyn's explanation.  

My childhood was bereft of dragons and the like so I appreciate this dive into dragondom.

Pretty smooth sailing with only a few hiccups, and enjoyable fill. My only quibble is HEREBEDRAGONS. As Caitlin pointed out, this was phrase put at the end of maps (rarely, apparently) to warn of unknown dangers in unexplored territory. I can’t find any references real or fictional where it would have been used to actually warn knights away from anything (seems like it would have been more of an incentive). I think it’s a fantastic (both meanings intended) marquee entry, but if you are going to use it why not clue it in its historical context which would have been equally as puzzling and interesting and actually teach people something.

A few nice clues, and good fill in general, but this was far too easy for a Saturday.

3/10

Much more like a Friday than a Saturday for me.

This week was a strange one for me:  I had almost the same time for Wednesday (worse than usual), Thursday (a bit better than usual) and today (significantly better than my usual Saturday time).

I was LOLing out loud when I got KARATELESSONS and MINIDONUTS.  There were a number of other nice little clues as well.  As a cartophile of sorts, I love old maps that say “here be monsters” so HEREBEDRAGONS resonated with me too.

I had a glitch at the end.  I had entered ers instead of ORS and no idea about the ESPN nickname so oche seemed as plausible as anything.  It took me a minute or two to figure out my mistake, but not so long as to spoil my enjoyment of this fresh puzzle.

Can someone explain the answer to "Heat setting, maybe"? 

Thank you!
TIL "Legally Blonde" is supposed to be a pun on Legally Blind

Smooth debut with a lot of character. Not as Saturday as some I've done but that's cool. 

Had Maya for Magi for a while. Loved Here Be Dragons but thought the clue could use some retooling; the one map that has that legend is ca. 1500, somewhat past the heyday of knighthood; more likely those who would consult such a map would be a mariner, a merchant, or a soldier. I kinda wish Sam Lyons, font of information on many things classical & medieval, would make an appearance and correct me on this, stop me from acting like a priggish pedant. Sam -- we miss you!

Mini donuts, karate lessons, urban decay, magi, such a rich and varied word-set... I always understood Yom Tov to refer to a class of holidays, not a term for a singular holiday like Yom Kippur, but since there are some holiday days that are Yom Tov days (kind of like sabbath days but with some differences in allowable meal preparation), it's kosher and I'm splitting hairs...again...
I liked it.

I've been trying my hand at puzzle construction for some time now. I have to admit that Ms. Ziegler is faring better than I, for now. 
However, I'm a much better dancer.

The long fills seemed so easy— but don't they always once they are in there?  I finished much more quickly than anticipated, after I had a lot of nothing the first pass(es).  But I reset my focus to offbeat, and I can't TELL you what a different it made.

Thank you, Maddy, that was funl.

When I'm eating my glazed ring-shaped treat, donut disturb me.

(Nothing will torus apart.)
That's the second time I put in Sonoma when the answer had to be Sonora.  I will never learn from my mistakes. Sonoma is nowhere close to Sonora.

Solved in just under 13 minutes, nearly half my usual solving time for a Saturday. Very nice fill, as others have appreciated, but the clues need some work. Just a little too straightforward. That's ok. I'm sure this constructor will offer us some brain twisters in the future.

Would have finished so much quicker but I didn't get the music so another fifteen mins later, I realise it's COMETOABADEND, not CaMETOABADEND. I didn't help that I'd never heard of a HORA before 🫣

HEREBEDRAGONS - despite the explanation - was most unpleasant 🤣

I know some of y'all are tripping cos it's was more of a Friday  crossword but there's nothing wrong with skipping leg day once in a while. Enjoy it. It's only a crossword. Calma! 😃
Good thing I saw twelfth night today

Did anyone else wonder if the crossword constructor was the young dancer from SIA's videos? https://youtu.be/2vjPBrBU-TM?si=ovcWU9z3JgAJ5VPV They're not the same Maddie/Maddy Ziegler, but I guess it would have been fitting since Sia appears so often in NYT crossword puzzles.
Genuinely thought the constructor was the young woman from Dance Moms and Sia’s former muse. Second ever sub 8 minute Saturday solve, so that’s exciting!
My eighth sub 2 minute Saturday solve, so exciting!

I didn’t get my gold star because for the life of me I couldn’t see why SIAN and ISS were errors. I’ve seen the name Sean spelled as SIAN recently, and figured since Maddy Ziegler worked for an attorney ISS might stand for International Stenographer Society or something similar. Nevertheless, I enjoyed this puzzle much more than a few others this week. Thanks, Ms. Ziegler!
Wow I had no idea the Ocho turned into a real channel. Lots of fun answers here, thanks!
This Saturday was so fun and my personal best time at 6:31! The fill definitely made me laugh.

As others have noted, this was on the easier side: At a little over 10 minutes, this was far and away my fastest Saturday (previous record was something like 15).

But I’m not coming here to brag (others have and will continue to post much better times!) or complain (I’m happy for a break!). I’m coming here to say that the fill was excellent, and the constructor did a fantastic job. Staring at the finished puzzle, I really have to admire how it all fits together. The only difference between this and a “hard” Saturday solve is the lack of obfuscation around a handful of clues. If some of the longer entries (say RIDDLE ME THIS, COLD OPENS, HERE BE DRAGONS, COME TO A BAD END, NOT A GOOD IDEA) had been the result of misleading wordplay rather than clued directly, this could have easily taken double the time. Easy tweaks the editors could have pushed for if they wanted to; clearly, they wanted to be nice to us this week.
stadium sales = gate? does that make sense somehow?

Moved to comment as I didn’t enjoy this one. I find too many clues that are in quotation marks or end in a question mark or ‘perhaps’ annoying. Maybe because of playing from another country where the lexicon / sayings are different, but it feels like guessing rather than solving.

Congratulations on a fun NYT debut, Ms Ziegler!

The KARATE LESSONS clue is wonderful — I don’t even mind that I tried KARATE claSseS first.  And HERE BE DRAGONS is a wonderful phrase that my husband and I work into conversation whenever we can. 

Hope we see you back here soon.

I got a PB today by three seconds over my previous one.  I’ve been solving so long - over 3400 puzzles since using the app - that PBs are very rare for me any more. I don’t usually pay much attention to times, other than on Sundays, but this one zipped by so fast for me that I had to look.  I enjoyed the snappy fill!  This puzzle put a sweet cap on a fun day. Thank you, Ms. Ziegler!

I really enjoyed this puzzle. Loved the Here be dragons, and Come to a bad end, etc. All just barrels of fun. It took me an hour,  which after reading all the much shorter times posted tonight, brought up a chuckle. I'm just so darn happy to solve one of these glorious things that an hour for a Saturday is a thrill for me. Some times a Saturday takes a few days at least. I've been doing crosswords for many years, and I love them. But I'm not fast and have been known to go down a rabbit hole or two when I find a word that fascinates me or one I want to know more about. So, if there are any newbies out there, don't be discouraged by the quick players and the wunderkinds, this is a game for us slow poke, plod alongs as well. I'm almost 80 and have been cross wording for decades and still having fun. It's not a competition, thank goodness. It's a wonderful opportunity to keep learning, have a laugh or two, and to appreciate all the brilliant minds that construct these marvels. Y'all have a great Labor Day week end. ✌️
Great job with this one, I really enjoyed it

Really enjoyed it. Surprisingly easy for a Saturday. Solved in under 20 min, a PB for me (I´ve been solving for a couple of years but I´m half non-anglo and tend to miss out on a lot of references) but the fill was SO good. 

I came up with a theme and want to try my hand at constructing and submitting and when I see fill like this in a debut it´s honestly intimidating, heh. Congrats!

Too easy by far for a Saturday. 

What’s the explanation for the clue used as the title of the column today?

Not sure what I think… some easy, some impossible if you’re not local… think I would’ve finished in 20 minutes if I were American. 
Karate lessons was great as was Here be dragons.
Heat setting MEET? What gives?
Would someone please explain 26D (Wedding reception highlight, maybe / HORA)?

What a fun Saturday puzzle! I hit occasional snarls, but then an "Aha!" on a longer entry would come along. I enjoy the little rush you get when one or two letters is enough to get an answer like 'HERE BE DRAGONS" or "KARATE LESSONS." And ESPN 8 May be one of my favorite clues ever. Now someone needs to work in "If you can dodge a wrench, you can dodge a ball."

Congratulations on your first NYT crossword puzzle, Maddy.  

Lots of great debut entries, and [Kick-starter program] for KARATE LESSONS made me laugh.
Some really good clues in here but I’m sorry you shouldn’t be able to get away with 26A
Fun puzzle! What's not to love about mini-donuts!

Okay this puzzle was very good but was way, way, way too easy for a Saturday. There’s nothing wrong with a fun, easy, well-constructed themeless. But not in the Saturday NYT. This is the fault of the editor, not the constructor.

Others have already mentioned wondering for a moment whether the constructor could be the dancer and actress who worked with Sia, but that’s Maddie Ziegler. I have found myself glancing at the byline ever since the surprise of seeing Natasha Lyonne’s name at the top of a NYT crossword. That was April 2, 2019, for anyone interested. (I don’t know how to link to a particular puzzle.)

A fairy tale beginning.  Maddy’s been making puzzles for less than two years and she lands a Times Saturday.  Bravo!

Apt to have an outstanding set of first-time NYT answers in a debut puzzle.  There are eight, including beauties ON THE BEAT NOT A GOOD IDEA, and HERE BE DRAGONS.  I don’t remember ever hearing the latter but it’s so quirky and sounds so pitch-perfect, that I love it.  It’s my favorite answer in the puzzle.

That middle stack is popping with spark (two answer debuts and one once-before) – three abutting 13s with zero ugly crosses.  Wow!

I liked the mini-theme of titles, with SENOR, EMIRS, MAYOR, and a backward SRI.  I loved [Heat setting, perhaps] for MEET – wordplay, direct clue, and opaque, all at the same time. Mwah!

Congratulations, Maddy, and it’s clear to me that you’ve got the knack.  I’m hoping for more … please?  Thank you for a splendid outing!
Delightful puzzle. Very doable and intuitive.

Unusually enjoyable Saturday puzzle. Not all that easy for me, of course, and had to look up a couple of things but then just working the crosses and pondering and lots of 'aha' moments when something finally dawned on me. Eight debut answers in this one, but none of them really unusual things or terms. COMETOABADEND was the only one completely unfamiliar to me and that's no big deal. One puzzle find today was inspired by our constructor's name. For no discernible reason I just wondered about 'Z' answers and stumbled across a Saturday from August 11, 2007 by Karen M. Tracey. Some answers in that one: JOEISUZU FLORENZZIEGFELD BENITEZ ALJAZEERA EZIOPINZA Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=8/11/2007&g=36&d=A Might put another puzzle find in a reply. ...
Fast and fresh. Good Wednesday themeless.
I had to look up IMANI because I never heard of NANAS (as “Grams”) either… BUT now I just “got it” in writing this comment!  Sheesh.  I guess that question mark was significant.
Congratulations on your NYT debut, counselor! Loved the fresh fill.

I solve on my phone, so the letters are tiny. For 6 across, I saw the "ri" as the letter "n," which elicited a "been there, done that" response. I remember, in particular, an evening that a friend and I spent lying on our backs on top of an ancient mound in Alabama, when I watched the stars circle around Van Gogh style.

Solved this one via my wits and knowledge alone, so I'm here to get my self esteem pruned back by a few anticipated "Wednesday level" complaints.

What did people think of the repetition of NANAS and NANNY?  Personally, I'm not a fan.
Call it my "nit du jour".

And a cruciverbalist's question:  Has there ever been a Norwegian king whose name was anything but OLAF? 
[insert winking emoji]

Found this one much less challenging that yesterday's puzzle, which took me about twice as long to solve.

"27A Heat setting, perhaps" almost got me, with my brain pulling up MEAT rather than MEET. But surely SABASTIAN was wrong, and then I realized that a heat might be part of a track meet, for example.

Not a fan of this puzzle's geometry. Felt like I was solving five minis, and the puzzle never felt quite "whole" to me.  That said, the fill seemed solid and the long entries were interesting.
After floundering Thursday and Friday it's great to get back on track.

His KARATE LESSONS
had COME TO A BAD END
because HERE BE DRAGONS
and they're not here for the MINI DONUTS

Fun puzzle, but yet again, entirely too easy for a Saturday. Finishing at 18 minutes, 20 minutes faster than my Saturday average  makes a puzzle distinctly less fun. 

I suppose the Times is fine with losing the long time solvers - anyone have a source to a real challenging puzzle of the caliber of what a Times Saturday used to be?

Maybe the clue "Classic warning to a knight" for HERE BE DRAGONS made the entry seem contrived? Perhaps its most famous occurrence is on the Hunt-Lenox Globe from around 1500. Apparently the globe is now the property of the New York Public Library. From https://www.rochester.edu/newscenter/worlds-oldest-globe-hunt-lenox-lazarus-project-417532/ The Hunt-Lenox Globe’s small size, dark color, and armature—the stand in which it sits—conspire to conceal the details of its surface. The land masses etched upon it include two areas representing the New World: one in the location of South America and the other, a mysterious, large island in the southern Indian Ocean. There are hard-to-spot artistic elements, too: sea monsters, ships, shipwrecks, and, just below the equator, the warning “Hic Sunt Dracones,” or “Here Be Dragons.”
No junk fill! And the cluing is really good. I solve for fun, not time, and this one hit my Saturday sweet spot. Well done Maddy!

I know I'm supposed to want a more difficult puzzle on a Saturday but I didn't today. This was fun. I thought  "grams," heat setting" and "way out" were all pretty clever. A lot of fresh, fun word play in this puzzle.
This one clicked for me, smooth solve.  Having bashed my head against many Saturdays, no complaints here.

Started this last night after a long day and shut it because I wasn’t making much progress. This morning after my usual chores (dog out and fed, cat input and output taken care of, bird feeders filled and out in the yard), and fueled by a cup of coffee, the puzzle clicked into place and I ended up solving it around 30% under my average time.

This morning, clues that flummoxed me last night just seemed delightfully clever: “Little dippers” for MINI DONUTS; “Kick-starter program” for KARATE LESSONS; “Heat setting” for MEET. 

Congratulations to Maddy Ziegler for a first-rate puzzle.

Continuation of a great week of puzzles! I didn't have much as I worked top to bottom, but then URBANDECAY and YACHT (having just been my 2nd Wordle guess today) got the ball rolling. Really enjoyed the cluing. 
Oh! It's Saturday - cleaning time.

Um...how is this puzzle "torrid"??

I enjoyed the solve, especially noting RIDDLE ME THIS (quite old-fashioned, really) and HERE BE DRAGONS (even older.)

I will say, though, that this is not the usual Saturday Toughie.  I got 30A off the C (with no other crossings at the time) and the only AHA Moment was when KARAT turned into KARATE!

Nonetheless...congrats to Maddy and earnest wishes for her bringing us more!

[What no proctologist wants to do]

Is it just me or did Caitlin make a kinda libellous claim about Benjamin Franklin DeCosta?


"The Hora! The Hora!"
"Yeah, yeah, after the ceremony, Kurtz."


COME TO A BAD END

I find it interesting that the clues that are listed as tricky in the column are usually ones I did not find particularly tricky.  It is usually others that trip me up.   Like, how does "Meet" relate to the clue "Heat setting, perhaps", or clues about obscure authors/actors/screenwriters, etc, or that require specific knowledge of games or shows that only those that played or watched them would have.

I loved many of today's entries, but my favorite was 52A. Almost inevitably, when I tell someone that I have a master's degree in ETHNOmusicology, they'll ask "what's that?" When I explain, their response is generally some variation of "oh, that sounds really interesting!"

My usual time of about 40 minutes - and very enjoyable. 

The only wedding reception highlight I could think of was cake (cutting of) and even with ORA could not guess HORA. One to remember.

Then had to reveal the C of OCHE and COLD OPENS - don't know of them or the clues.

Even more obscure was MINIDONUTS, which I now read are dipped in coffee in the USA. Soggy doughnuts, no thanks!

Finally, why ALUM and '22/'23? I looked up ALUM but can't see any connection to these numbers.

A good workout, some great clues, as others have mentioned.

Wow. 
Saturday was 1 minute slower than Monday. 
Friday was 5 minutes longer than Thursday and Saturday combined. 

 Wanted to think I was ‘smart’.  But I knew this would be considered very easy per that xword stat site. 

Just did Friday and Saturday. 
Not jewish. And these last two days have been hurting my solves.  Yesterday. I was sure it was beth instead of BNAI.  and i would never gotten HORA without three crosses. 

My favorite hangup was putting saxophone was “violas twin brother”. because I had the opening S. I figured brother was some musical interpretation of a classical piece called “twelfth night”. 

Anyway. Very breezy after struggling with Friday just before.
Nyoom! 8:18 for a Saturday. Felt like a rockstar.

A Saturday record for me in a steady back-and-forth manner and a thoroughly enjoyable solve. I was really puzzled by MEET, which is pretty funny because I used to run track. In my defense, I was a middle distance runner so we didn't have heats, but still.

I thought the "classic warning" was HERE  BE DRAGONS, or tygers, or spoilers, but if it's translated from Latin, I'll let it go. Besides, it was a funny clue, with the knight and all. For death awaits you, with nasty, nasty teeth.

Also, reminded of the SNL skit with Robert Smith of The Cure on "This Old House." The joke is that he rather likes the URBAN DECAY, and won't let the crew fix anything.
This puzzle, crisp and fun as it was, should have appeared on a Wednesday.
Congratulations on a great debut with very satisfying longer fill.  I always appreciate links to the constructor's portfolios/websites so thanks for that Caitlin.

I'm at the airport ready to fly back home from holiday, so I'm disengaging vacation mode and going back to my daily routines, which include solving NYT puzzles. We're getting a puppy on Monday though so I might not have time to do anything else but care for him 🤣.

It's a good thing today's grid was easy for a Saturday - I'm probably one rusty solver after three weeks off. 

I completed the puzzle without outside help but I don't get why "Fashion plate, maybe" solves to MODEL. Any help?

Really struggled getting through this, thought I was dead but pushed through for a very rare, hint-less Saturday solve.

And then, as always, come here to see everyone complaining about how easy it was. Crosswords will never not make me feel stupid. Thanks NYT.

Record time for me, which can be disappointing on a Saturday. My coffee is still hot enough for donut dipping!

Despite being over too fast, it was fun with a lot of great clues and overall a satisfying solve.

Congratulations Maddy on your debut. An elegant puzzle. Loved KARATE LESSONS and HERE BE DRAGONS. 
I had HUH before HEH and MEAT before MEET. (A microwave heat setting?)
I liked the clue for YACHT. When I saw Bahla fort I thought  “wait a minute!, I know that place, I’ve been there. Where was it? Ah yes, nestled in the Jebel Akhdar range of Oman.” 
How sad, young lady, that you consider me old enough to be SPRY!
the "here be dragons" link was fun, and I noticed that next to the dragons off of southern Africa was a two-tailed mermaid. so the recent siren theme has legs. ;)

had so much fun with this one!!! it’s not often that a saturday comes easy to me, usually i’m looking up clues from the very start to get me going, but today felt like i was on the right wavelength from the get-go. i did have lots of trouble with 27A 24D crossing though—started out with SEBASTIAN, but changed it to SaBASTIAN to get MEaT, since MEET made no sense to me at all until checking these comments. Added a good five minutes to my finishing time after checking every entry for spelling mistakes. had good fun with 34A and 49A, and was happy to see my guess for 1D was correct!

Didn't "get" MEET/MODEL, HORA, HEH or YOM but got the crosses and still beat my average by 40 min so, tough but fair.

HERE BE DRAGONS and KARATE LESSONS were my favorite.

GREAT NYT debut! Enjoyed it immensely, even if I was trying to suss out KAR_TELETHONS for the longest time. And Heat Setting? Genius!

I did figure out RIDDLEMETHIS right off the bat, and COMETOABADEND didn't take much longer. 

Totally enjoyable!
Most of it was pretty easy even for me, with autocheck. But when I came back this morning with one empty square, I still had to do an alphabet run where 48D crosses 50A.

I enjoyed this puzzle, but it did go quickly for a Saturday. I topped it off with a Thursday puzzle chosen haphazardly from the archives, and this one didn't disappoint. For those of you wanting more, try: https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/daily/2013/08/01

I think this may have the best week ever for quality crosswords.  All straightforward, many requiring a total rethink of the clue.

Wondering if anyone else was tripped up by saint in 1A, and being so sure that was the answer that it was only late in my solve I realized there was an alternative.

I started this last night and got about half way through before I couldn’t keep my eyes open a second longer. Like I fell asleep with my phone on my chest tired 😴 Woke up late this morning to finish and breezed through the rest of it. Unlike many others before my comment, I got MEET on my first try. I was on our swim team through high school and was very familiar with heats at a MEET. Superb clueing for that one. I MEAN IT! Like others, I also loved the clue for KARATE LESSONS. Brilliant. Looking forward to seeing more from you, Maddy Ziegler!!
A fast Saturday, but with some great kicks! I had to look at 27A three or four times before it clicked. 34A was good fun. Great job!

One more puzzle find. A Thursday from June 15, 1995 by Norma Steinberg. I don't recall seeing this trick used before, and I found this one quite amusing. One theme clue/answer in that one: Worthless agreements? : MTPROMISES And the other theme answers: MEWINNERS JAMESAG KSERASERA EZCOMEEZGO Here's that Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=6/15/1995 And there was previous puzzle with pretty much the same trick. A Sunday from March 1, 1981 by Jordan S. Lasher with the title: "Look B-4 U solve." Some of those theme answers: KSERASERA CULATERALLIGATOR 24THECSAW YBABYY PSOUPY DEEPBLUEC YSANDWHERE4S CHOWTHEYRUN IISIR And there were several more. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=3/1/1981&g=19&d=A ...
Question - How does stadium sales become GATE? I could see seats or tickets. What am I missing about gate?
Loved this one!! Thanks, Maddy!

Like many a Saturday, it was a slow start for me. I finally cracked it open with the SE. I had several lucky guesses and a few I was sure were wrong but couldn't be (MEET, GATE). As always, some confident early mistakes too (HuH, swag for "giveaway", went back and forth between ORS and eRS).
Fabulous cluing for the long entries! So much fun. 
And now I'm craving the MINI DONUTS we get every year during the Christkindlmarkt. 😋

I am surprised to see so many "this was easy"comments.    I really struggled on the left half of the puzzle.    I kept thinking it would be "beware dragons".   Also, cereal bars didn't come naturally to me, nor did Karate (soccer was on the brain).  Came in right at my average for a Saturday, which is a slow 1 hour.

Finished in short order, then spent 10 minutes trying to find my error. Similar to yesterday's, it came down to a single clue that eventually--but then quite suddenly--transformed itself as I stared at it. I'm apparently not the only one who was thinking microwave settings before athletic events.

I'm reminded of a cat who once owned me, who learned that if she stared at a door long enough, it would change from closed to open. I'm learning to work similar magic by staring at clues. If nothing happens, it just means I haven't stared long enough.

Loved this challenging puzzle, but I still don’t get MEET as a heat setting.
Lil help please. Thanks.
Heat setting - MEET? I get the meaning but that definition is a real stretch.
I thought I’d solved in record time for me, and then spent 5 more minutes figuring out the MEAT vs MEET issue. Glad to know I wasn’t alone in my befuddlement.

All rise — court is in session!
Fun opening statement puzzle, Attorney Maddy!

MEET as in track/swim heats to winnow the field of competitors
YOM as in day (e.g., Yom Kippur)
HORA is a circle dance, highlighted by raising the honoree(s) such as a (skittish) bride and groom up and down in chairs while the newlyweds hold a kerchief and keep their balance

Easy Saturday, Rebus Wednesday, Reverse Mini, and other switcheroos this week were enjoyable diversions.
Seemed to be more direct knowledge, factual answers than typical, which got me wondering if this was a trivia test rather than a crossword puzzle.
Some really great clues. Thanks!
Are the puzzles getting easier or am I getting faster? Enjoyed it.
New Saturday record for me! Not disappointed; my brain could use the relaxation. I see some others found it more challenging, which is to be expected.
Can someone tell me what 27 across means? I’m totally clueless. Why is that word a heat setting?
Never mind. Saw it in the article. That’s pretty obscure. BOOO! Though I guess it IS Saturday.
Why are there TWO silent letters in "yacht"? Doesn't the H mean it's pronounced as rhyming with "not"? If the H was silent, wouldn't it rhyme with "fat"?

This was fun until the end, when I had to finish the SW corner. By the time I was done, I racked up 1h 18m unaided. No idea who the director is. 

I had to use linguistic sleuthing for a good number of entries, which is enjoyable.

Just adding to the data for the NYT team.
There is an excellent brewery near me called Vicious Fishes with an even more excellent IPA called “Here Be Dragons.” Alas, it didn’t help me in the solve. Cheers!🍻
Even tho I eventually figured the classic knights warning, for some reason I thought it was HERE COMES RAIN for the longest time.

51:39, 10 faster than average. Had OLAF filled in first but deleted it convinced that the down entry was LANAE. Finally gave in and looked up OLAF, fixed MONAE and completed it. Just the right amount of crunch for a Saturday and loved the long phrases.

satisfyingly LABORious fun xword

used to only do sundays...
but my faves are now
"thursdays and saturdays"

as referenced in what classic
CSN song?

and while we're at it
what deceased SNL alum
designed their logo?

unlike many commenters herein...

most of my xword enjoyment 
is total disregard for times
streaks bests averages etc.
and just enjoying the solve process
including groans of frustration
loads of LOLs
and ultimately the completion 
no matter how long it takes

have been known to stretch
a solve over several days
if necessary

getting answers the 2nd time
around that eluded me before

where was that part of my brain
yesterday???

resorting to autocheck
or lookups only when
absolutely necessary
so as not to throw
or break anything

do love coming to this forum
if I've had a slog 
in one area of the grid 
to find that most solvers did too
apparently misery does enjoy company

LOL

is there are nickname
a la REBUS
and if there isn't 
there should be
for a completed grid
that prompts one of 
those dang popups:

close but no cigar
oh whoops somethings amiss
horsefeathers at least 
one square is wrong

triggering another fun element
of cruciverbalism:

a columboesque forensic 
sifting thru the grid 
in search of 
the renegade guilty square(s)

and then of course 
the thrill of 
"finding the killer" 

LOL

happy safe long wknd all!
I've been gone for a few days. I had a surprise appendectomy last Sunday night, so I didn't do the puzzle for three days. Modern surgery is amazing. Finished very slow today!
That was a gem of a puzzle. Thank you Maddy!

As much as I love the OCHO reference, MEET / MEAT / HEAT was just a little too TWEE.

@Steven M.

You solved this in 12 minutes, but you think you might not get a gold star because it's a Sunday?

That brings a question to my mind that I've never really thought about before:  how frequently do you fast solvers (12 for a Saturday, any Saturday, seems really fast to me) fail to get a gold?

I've always assumed that someone who could do a puzzle like this in 12 minutes could easily at least finish any puzzle of the week, ignoring time.

But is that true?  Are slowpokes like me getting the same solve percentage, just multiple times more slowly?

@Francis I fail Sunday more than any other day of the week. It's just a volume thing. There's more opportunities for errors and Naticks on the bigger grid.

I am currently on a 42 Day streak, my longest ever, but I probably usually miss one to three days a month, two being the average the past few months. The last Saturday I missed was mid July, with AIRESDALE/SAID (I had Liresdale/Slid)
@Steven M., I actually find Saturdays significantly harder than Sundays. Sundays take me longer because of the grid size, but the elaborate themes tend to make the solving easier.

@Steven M.

I guess my astonishment was at my own naivety, who thought that if someone could solve a Saturday puzzle in 12 minutes, then they could have solved a twice as hard puzzle in 24 minutes.  

In other words, it never occurred to me that a super speedy solver could just get stuck, incapable of knowing something they didn't know.

You don't seem to have taken any offense, and I surely meant none, but I'm throwing this final sentence out just in case.

@Francis

I’ve been surprised at @Steven M’s not always finishing a puzzle, too. I’m a pretty speedy solver (sub-10 today, had to chase down 2 typos) and by the time I had got my average Saturday times to about 20 minutes, finishing any NYT puzzle was a question of when, not if, because I had a couple years’ worth of them under my belt, plus some archives. Which makes me think that Steven is naturally a super quick thinker who, after some more experience, will be matchless at this.

@Solverado

Thanks, that was a great answer to my question.  I do believe the "quick thinking" part is limiting--I've never felt I was good under intense pressure or when I needed a very fast response ("Jeopardy" literally scared me, even though as I got older I knew most of the answers.)

So it sounds to me one has a better prognosis of becoming a star solver if one is fast, but sometimes misses, rather than someone who never misses, maybe out of refusal to give up.  But is never fast.  

The less successful person will get more successful, but the slower person won't get that much faster.

@Solverado @Francis 

I also think that perhaps *some* fast-thinking solvers (and this isn't specific to Steven) are less willing to muddle, mull, and tinker over a puzzle than (us) slower solvers to get those last few toughies. (Because they'd almost surely eventually get them.)

(On occasion,  "muddling" for me includes running the alphabet for a letter or two and so some of my solves would not be gold stars if I were a paper solver!!) 

It's fun to ponder...
Could be they are just busy in life and don't actually have the time; could be that they prefer to get it done in one sitting; could be that they know they have an error somewhere but trying to find it is too tedious.

I am slow for sure but quite stubborn/patient about correctly finishing a puzzle if at all possible. 

The AHA!!!! feeling of waking up or thinking of the answer when walking or doing something else is my 100% favorite part of puzzling so I think I kind of prefer the ones that take me forever.

My streak is never very long (I'm at like 48 or something) but that's nearly always because life got in the way and I got behind and missed the time window because I didn't even start the puzzle (which is about 3 days.)

I eventually solve it cleanly but that gives a blue star. Oh well! 

In fact, I can look back at the calendar and the blue stars perfectly correlate to stressful or busy periods 😬😬😬.

Always love participating in these thought-provoking discussions in this amazing community. ❤️❤️❤️❤️❤️

@Francis

A lot has to do with confidence.  When you have the “when, not if” epiphany, you become determined to figure every so-called Natick out with reasoning and lateral thinking, recall and just common sense.

@Francis

A concrete example just a few threads after this one is Marshall’s, in which he put ERS for ORS at 13D, which is a reasonable guess, and so he had OCHE for 10A.  He thought that was as good a guess as any, since he had never heard of the actual answer. But the clue was [Another name for ESPN8, with "the"], which has a very big hint buried in it.

I’ve never heard of ESPN8, even though I have the full sports package on my TV, but I caught the 8 in the clue.  That led me to a Spanish number, which went in immediately (maybe even before ORS).

Being able to take advantage of built-in hints like that one is what gives you confidence.  Once you have that confidence, you realize you can always figure it out.  Puzzles are created to be solved, not to stump you.

Apologies, Marshall, for making your error my example.

@Matt
Not quite redundant. Yom = day. Tov = good and, more loosely in conjunction with YOM, special. So YOMTOV = holiday. It is used this way in speaking; e.g., "Do you have a new outfit for yomtov?" contains no wish although it does use the combined form YOMTOV. So, "Good yomtov" = "Have a good holiday."

@Francis

I expect there is a strong correlation, largely based on experience. There are words that fit well in a crossword puzzle (usually with lots of vowels) that are not nearly as common in the wild.

After working lots of puzzles, you just kind of automatically drop those in, which makes for more crosses and a quicker solve.

Plus, later in the week, experience teaches that the most obvious answer is more likely than not incorrect, so it’s worth considering what the misdirection might be. This makes for fewer mistakes and incorrect crosses, which is what usually slows me down the most, rather than blank space.

@Francis

I don’t think my answer will be helpful, but I solved it clean in pen in the paper. I get the weekend paper delivered, and I’ll practice my precision skills by doing those puzzles in pen. Obviously that varies my time, because it’s easier to put the puzzles down and pick them up later. When I’m in the app, I’ll sit and finish the puzzle, but I’m less wary of making mistakes if that makes sense. 

I can’t tell you how long it took me in total to solve that puzzle, but my app time was 4 minutes 5 seconds. I remember I mistyped an answer and had to hunt that down rather than it being a solve error.

@Amy

Agreed, and it's not only cultural differences. Many of these are not set phrases in American English either, just two words that happen to go together. I also find it somehow dispiriting. I found some of the cluing very questionable.

In case it helps, a ? in a clue indicates wordplay, though the use of this is not consistent. 

And speaking of wordplay, I don't consider"Legally Blonde" a pun. Wordplay yes, pun no. "Santa Clause" is a pun, because it uses the same sound to create a different word, which also makes a kind of sense.
Teresa, Re: blonde / blind Puns may involve double meanings, or words "similar in sound;" homophones are not required. https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/pun

@Teresa

There’s a Wikipedia page on it! It’s a thing. Although it apparently never actually appeared on old maps (except a couple of globes from the 1500s) but it’s commonly used on recreations/maps meant to look like they’re from the Middle Ages, in media, and as a metaphorical phrase for danger. There’s a number of books/movies etc with the title (T)here Be Dragons (most/all using it in the metaphorical sense).

@Cindy Here’s one crossnerd :) term that crops up occasionally and may be new to you: “dook”. It’s when the parsing of the fill gives one pause as in “what the heck is a dook?”, when it is meant to be read as “do OK”. HANDYNASTY has caused some confusion until parsed as HAN DYNASTY.

@Bonnie Ann

What a wonderful, even eye-moistening, post!

You made me think of something I thought a long time ago about golf.  Why, if you like swinging and hitting the ball so much, do you strive to do it as few times as possible?

There are of course good answers to that, but it still rings as slightly counter-intuitive.

Same thing with time in a crossword.  I come here to for the time of the puzzle solution, basically give myself permission to not think about any of the horrible things I can't fight off the rest of the day.  Why should I want to rush through that?

Another example:  speed reading.  I would love to be able to read John Updike at about ten words per minute, letting every sinuous sentence surprising me before it vanishes.  I'm not a fast reader by any means, or even average speed, but there are times I wanted to slow down (or is it "slow up" re: an earlier puzzle).

@Teresa

The only reason to do a puzzle quickly, in my estimation, is if you're going to compete at a tournament. Then, speed is of the essence. During the 10 years I attended the ACPT in Stamford, I was always looking for ways to speed up my game. After I stopped going, (because life had other ideas), I learned to savor the puzzle for its own sake. But that's just me. I'm very competitive when I'm playing something like a board game, but crosswords are a solitary pleasure, so there's no need for speed in my solves.

@Bonnie Ann (et. al.) 

I'll join the chorus (daddy sings bass). Not at all interested in speed solving. Don't' really care at all about how long it takes me. Just enjoy working things out. 

Glad to be in good company. 

...

Times Rita,

The "solve for time" folks who post here seem to like to compete with their own times, if not with the times of others, even if they are not at a tournament (where you yourself competed).

You may not solve for speed now (as I don't), but you should understand the concept.

@Times Rita

Many people who mention their times here are not speed solving. They just solve faster than other people, like some people walk faster than others without intending to speed walk.  

Often, the mention of solving times has to do with how difficult the puzzle is perceived to be relative to others (cf. the bear of a Byron Walden puzzle two weeks ago), or to point out one’s improvement or difficulty. 

Sometimes, though, experienced solvers spice up a Monday puzzle by seeing how fast they can solve one. Since a Monday solve is just too easy to be a challenge to a very experienced solver, speed solving can just be a way to make it interesting.  (You can also solve across or downs only.)

The extended fun time is had by participating in that comments.

@Bonnie Ann

I enjoyed reading your comment (as always). 

As Steve L likes to say (more or less), solving quickly is just a natural thing for some of us. It’s hard to go slower than the pace that feels right to you. 

As long as someone is enjoying the time spent with a crossword, it doesn’t matter if it’s 10 minutes or two hours. 

I hope you have a great Labor Day weekend, too. More importantly, I hope that first cool weather comes to Central Texas sooner rather than later. I don’t at all miss those summers that last until October.

@Francis
In those electrifying moments when I begin a story and see that the writing is going to be very, very good, and I'm torn between wanting to know what's going to happen and wanting to savor the imagery and perceptiveness and power of the language, I know that I can read it again, so I  just open the gate and let the story flow. 

When a crossword is beautifully crafted, I can try to race through it, or slow down and admire the skill and imagination and humor of the construction, but either way, when I finish it, I wish that the train had not just rushed on, or that my journey on it could be longer. Still, I know I can go back over the puzzle and enjoy the cleverness of the clues and fills.

This analogy can apply to so much of life, but it's the experience that is important and should be  savored.  Memories and objective admiration are okay, but awareness in the moment is key to everything.

@The X-Phile

Before I started reading Wordplay and Diary of a Crossword Fiend five years ago, I never knew that a quasi duplication like NANAS and NANNY was a no-no. 

Even now, I rarely notice such things. But this one prompted me to comment about it to my husband while I was solving (not that he’s very interested in such things). 

I wouldn’t say that it bothered me, but I did notice it.

@The X-Phile

I noticed them but consider them different words and fair game

@Barry Ancona
Ya beat me to it, dang ya.

@The X-Phile

Didn't bother me at all. In fact, I'd call it a feature rather than a bug. Two similar five-letter words in the same orientation, with one referring to humans and the other referring to a goat. ;-)
@The X-Phile There was actually once an entire category on Jeopardy called "Kings Named Haakon." And every time I see a clue about Norwegian kings I try that first. ONE DAY.....

@The X-Phile

I noticed it, but took NANAS as referring to 'grandmothers' (British) and NANNY as referring to someone employed by a family.

@Xword Junkie

I agree that today's puzzle felt like a second Friday.
And, like you, I'm not a fan of the kind of grid that feels like conjoined Minis, so that when you finish one region, you have little assistance for solving the rest of the puzzle.
But I didn't find that to be an issue today. The long answers gave a nice continuity to the puzzle, and I liked the central stack and the freshness of the answers.
@Xword Junkie -- FYI, this is the third time this grid design was used in the Times puzzle, first used by Robyn Weintraub in 2020.
@Xword Junkie aha!!! I finished the puzzle but needed your explanation for MEET! Thank you!

@Jane Wheelaghan Two kinds of donuts--both round with a hole in the middle, both deep-fried. But one is made from a yeast-raised dough; the other, from a wetter more cake-like dough/batter using baking powder.
